awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Adaptive Investments for Resilience of Electricity Infrastructure Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program project will: (i) generate new decision theories and models to help government policymakers in crafting the incentives to advance public-private enterprise capital formation and investments into electricity infrastructure systems; and (ii) investigate and provide self-organized restoration plans in the advent of a disruption. Inspired by the self-healing properties in biological systems such as morphogenesis (genes adapting to environmental changes) and wound healing (functional changes in cells due to regeneration), this CAREER project will expand the paradigms of complex adaptive systems by incorporating realism and empirical data into models that have practical implications such as how much to invest in a particular electricity technology portfolio in order to enhance system resilience. In addition to creating new decision theories in incentivizing players in the electricity market, one outcome will be a decision support platform for policymaking to enhance public-private enterprise participation in community resilience efforts. To integrate the research components into educational activities, this project will: (i) incorporate social innovation and entrepreneurship to reach students at all levels; (ii) create a hierarchical makerspace academy to provide high school and STEM students the knowledge to build empirical and analytical models of decision making by including project tasks in formal and informal learning processes; and (iii) integrate methods from economics, operations research, and biology with engineering knowledge. The multi-disciplinary approach will help broaden participation of underrepresented minorities in research and positively impact engineering education.

This research is at the nexus of predictive analytics used to forecast electric power disruptions and robust stochastic optimization models used to determine investments into energy technology portfolios under sequential and multiple uncertainties in policy and technological performance. This project will integrate these approaches in a bio-inspired complex adaptive system framework to evaluate performance-oriented dynamic investments, and use scenario analysis to distill the thresholds of resilience-enhancing electricity technology portfolios. The PI will interpret the system healing process to be a dynamic function of infrastructural decay, operating status/environment, adaptation, redundancy, and the potential for assets decentralization to limit disaster propensity for damage propagation and downtime protraction. This framework will employ the multiple Taylor Series function with wide area measurement system data for system stability prediction within a modified IEEE bus test system. This project will evaluate the value of a resilient infrastructure system in the larger scheme of systems interdependence with the aid of Integrated Assessment Models such as Global Change Assessment Model (GCAM) and Computable General Equilibrium (CGE) models infused with mathematical representations of physical system degradation. If successful, this CAREER project will provide the first scientific test of the efficacy of the multi-disciplinary approach.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

CAREER: Adaptive Investments for Resilience of Electricity Infrastructure System

1.0 Project Overview

The goal of this multi-year research project was to advance the resilience of electricity networks as a critical infrastructure system through dynamic investment modeling. This initiative aimed to provide decision-making tools for policymakers and industry leaders, create innovative approaches to electricity market resilience, and foster STEM education and outreach.

2.0 Key Research Outcomes

Significant advancements were made in several key areas:

1. Electricity Grid Resilience and Investment Modeling

  • Developed novel decision-theoretic models to optimize investments in electricity grid resilience.
  • Proposed strategies for integrating renewable and storage systems to enhance grid stability under varying policy scenarios.
  • Conducted case studies on security-constrained unit commitment (SCUC) models to assess the flexibility of power grids in response to uncertainty.
  • Investigated the role of firm-level self-reporting on environmental stewardship, revealing that financial markets often reward such reports despite inconsistencies in emissions reductions.

2. Self-Healing Systems in Electricity Networks

  • Conducted a comprehensive literature review on self-healing systems, drawing parallels between biological resilience and power system restoration.
  • Introduced mathematical models inspired by biological processes, such as decentralization and failure-recovery mechanisms, to enhance grid reliability.
  • Optimized network resilience through a decision-support framework that integrates power system stability predictions using IEEE test systems.

3. Impact of Renewable Energy and Electrification on the Energy Sector

  • Examined the interdependency of power generation, transportation, and CO2 emissions in the context of increasing electric vehicle (EV) adoption.
  • Used bottom-up energy modeling frameworks to assess policy interventions for reducing carbon footprints while maintaining economic feasibility.
  • Provided insights into the cost-effective deployment of community solar programs and their implications for sustainable energy transitions.

4. Application of Computational Methods in Energy Policy

  • Applied Hidden Markov Models (HMM) to predict power system failures and optimize maintenance strategies.
  • Investigated the efficiency of renewable energy adoption under uncertainty using Data Envelopment Analysis (DEA) combined with Monte Carlo simulations.
  • Explored the Computable General Equilibrium (CGE) modeling approach to understand the economic resilience of energy systems under various stress conditions.

3.0 Educational and Outreach Achievements

A significant component was dedicated to STEM education and community engagement.

**  Summer Modeling Academy for High School and Undergraduate Students

  • Successfully ran an annual summer intensive academy for high school students, focusing on systems modeling, data analytics, and optimization.
  • Provided hands-on training in spreadsheet automation, Python programming, and decision analysis tools.
  • Developed a hierarchical mentorship model engaging high school, undergraduate, and graduate students in collaborative learning.

**  Curriculum and Course Development

The project supported the enhancement of courses with contents related to the use of deterministic and stochastic decision models, integrated CGE models and policy simulations, and created case studies to illustrate real-world energy resilience challenges and solutions, now used in all curricula.

4.0 Broader Societal Impacts

The project had significant implications beyond academia, contributing to policymaking, energy equity, and workforce development:

  • Policy Engagement and Industry Collaboration: Outcomes informed discussions on regulatory frameworks for clean energy investments. Partnerships with stakeholders and national labs facilitated the translation of insights into actionable recommendations.
  • Broadened Talent Development in STEM: Broadened participation in engineering through educational programs with opportunities post-graduation.
  • Public Engagement: Engaged local high schools and universities in sustainability-focused curricula, promoting energy literacy and career pathways.
  • Summer Intensive Modeling Academy: Over 80 high school students participated in a four-to-six-week program that introduced them to data modeling, optimization, and decision analysis. Students developed practical skills in Python, Excel, and decision modeling with many proceeding to pursue their education in STEM.
  • Graduate and Undergraduate Mentorship: The project facilitated mentorship for graduate and undergraduate students, leading to collaborative publications and conference presentations.

5.0 Dissemination of Results

The project’s findings have been widely disseminated through peer-reviewed journal articles and conference presentations. Publications in high-impact journals such as IEEE Transactions on Engineering Management, Applied Energy, Advances in Applied Energy, Energy Policy, Utilities Policy, Computers and Industrial Engineering, Energy and Buildings, etc., underscore the research’s contribution to the field. The PI also gave invited talks at institutions including the Department of Energy Science and Engineering at Stanford University, Department of Systems and Information Engineering at the University of Virginia, the Irving Institute for Energy and Society at Dartmouth University, etc.

6.0 Conclusion

This project has successfully advanced knowledge in electricity system resilience, corporate environmental strategy, and infrastructure investment decision-making. By integrating cutting-edge decision science with real-world applications, this project contributes to a more resilient and equitable energy future for all. The findings of this project provide a strong foundation for future research in energy resilience, self-healing grids, and sustainable investment strategies. The educational and outreach components have strengthened STEM engagement, while the research findings have informed both policy and industry practices. Moving forward, the insights gained from this project will serve as a foundation for future research in self-healing infrastructure, stochastic investment models, and policy-driven clean energy adoption strategies.
